posts.description:
Happy #Caturday! Today is the purrfect day to visit our new exhibition #BeforeInternetCats in the Lawrence A. Fleischman Gallery, on the first floor of the @SmithsonianNPG. 
We hope you enjoy the exhibit, but don‚Äôt fur-get that while felines are certainly among the more adorable findings in our collections, they represent just a fraction of our vast resources. With more than 20 million items, the @ArchivesAmerArt is the world‚Äôs largest research center dedicated to documenting the history of the visual arts in the U.S. 
This concludes our takeover of the @Smithsonian Instagram this week. Follow us at @ArchivesAmerArt to see more highlights from our collections. 
#ArchivesCats #FelineFinds #CatsofInstagram #Catsagram

The time is meow! Our exhibition ‚ÄúBefore Internet Cats: Feline Finds from the Archives of American Art‚Äù is now open in our Lawrence A. Fleischman Gallery, on the first floor of the @SmithsonianNPG. 
The rare documents on view in #BeforeInternetCats reflect our enduring fascination with felines. Shown here are feline finds from the @archivesamerart's collections. Creators of the cat content are (from left to right): Lenore Tawney, Mark Green, Min√© Okubo, Jay DeFeo and Charles Buckley. üò∏üêàüê±üêæüôÄ #ArchivesCats #FelineFinds #CatsofInstagram #Catsagram #cats #purrfect

Before social media, we shared the details of our lives through snail mail. The Archives holds millions of letters that contain facts and anecdotes about the American art world, from seemingly mundane happenings to historical events. 
The papers of painter Hedda Sterne contain cat-themed correspondence from Georges Mathieu, a French painter. Here, Mathieu has embellished an oversize letter with a ribbon of adorable kittens. 
We‚Äôre the @archivesamerart taking over the @Smithsonian Instagram for the week to celebrate our new exhibition #BeforeInternetCats. üòª‚úâÔ∏è #ArchivesCats #FelineFinds #CatsofInstagram #Catsagram #cats #Cat-espondence

Here are some tiny snapshots of painter Jay DeFeo‚Äôs cat, Pooh. DeFeo was a Bay Area artist known for her monumental masterpiece ‚ÄúThe Rose.‚Äù These photos‚Äîprobably clipped from a contact sheet‚Äîwere taken in her studio on Fillmore Street in San Francisco. üòºüì∏ More photos of Pooh will be on view in the #BeforeInternetCats exhibition organized by @archivesamerart, which opens Friday. 
#ArchivesCats #FelineFinds #CatsofInstagram #Catsagram #cats #artiststudio

Photographs of artists in their studios enhance our understanding of artists‚Äô biographies, notably their working processes. For many artists, the studio is a solitary space for reflection and work. 
Cats often make ideal studio companions. They serve as sympathetic critics and elegant muses. In this photograph, Pozy the cat watches muralist Edna Reindel work in her California studio. Pozy is also the subject of the wall mural behind them. üòªüñå Follow us at @archivesamerart for more sneak peeks at our upcoming exhibition #BeforeInternetCats. 
#ArchivesCats #FelineFinds #CatsofInstagram #Catsagram #cats #artiststudio

Though Reginald Gammon was known for his evocative portraits of prominent African Americans, and not cats, in the mid-1960s he illustrated a children‚Äôs book that chronicles the friendship between a boy and a bespectacled cat. üê±üëì Cats from the @archivesamerart are taking over the @Smithsonian Instagram this week, giving you a look at our upcoming exhibition #BeforeInternetCats. 
#ArchivesCats #FelineFinds #CatsofInstagram #Catsagram #cats #storybook #creativeprocess

Thousands of sketches in the Archives of American Art offer insight into artists‚Äô creative processes. This 1948 sketchbook of watercolor studies by muralist and children‚Äôs book illustrator Emily Barto highlights the distinct personalities of several felines. üêàüìí
We‚Äôre the @archivesamerart taking over the @Smithsonian Instagram for the week to celebrate our new exhibition #BeforeInternetCats. 
#ArchivesCats #FelineFinds #CatsofInstagram #Catsagram #cats #sketchbooks #creativeprocess

Today is #EarthDay! üåéüåçüåè This 1980 button is in our @amhistorymuseum‚Äôs collection.

We‚Äôre sharing conservation success stories this weekend at our #EarthOptimism Summit‚Äîfollow along on Facebook and Twitter to learn about how science is working to solve complex problems around the globe.

Did you know the Smithsonian helped save the American bison from extinction? In this @smithsonianarchives photo, a group of kids look at the first bison at the National Zoo in 1899. #tbt 
When William Hornaday (later the first director of @smithsonianzoo) traveled to Montana in 1886 to collect specimens for an exhibition at the National Museum, he was surprised at how decimated the bison herds had become due to hunting. 
To educate the public about the importance of their conservation, he created an exhibition about them in the museum and even put live bison on display behind the Castle‚Äîa precursor to the Zoo in our own backyard. 
Learn about more conservation success stories this Friday through Sunday by following #EarthOptimism. 
#ThrowbackThursday
posts.localization: Smithsonian‚Äôs National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute

posts.description:
The ‚ÄúFirst Lady of Song,‚Äù Ella Fitzgerald, was born 100 years ago this month. üé∂
We‚Äôre celebrating the centennial of her birth and the legendary career that followed with this portrait on view at our @smithsoniannpg. 
It shows Fitzgerald performing, flanked by Ray Brown (left), Dizzy Gillespie (right) and Milt Jackson (far right). The photographer, William P. Gottlieb, learned to use a camera so that he could include images in his weekly music column for The Washington Post. 
Today, his photos of jazz musicians from the 1930s and ‚Äô40s are regarded as invaluable visual records of jazz‚Äôs Golden Age.

Did you know orchids make up 10 percent of the world‚Äôs plant species? But more than half of native orchids in North America are listed as threatened or endangered in some part of their home range. 
Researchers at @smithsonianenvironment are working to save the 200-plus species like this one, Galearis spectabilis, which is common in Maryland. 
They‚Äôre studying the interactions between orchids and fungi‚Äîa complex, symbiotic relationship in which each of the orchids‚Äô life stages depend to some extent on specific fungi. 
Learn about our conservation efforts and successes this week as we share stories on Facebook and Twitter with #EarthOptimism.

Happy #Easter! This early 20th-century postcard is one of more than 3,000 real photo postcards in our @amhistorymuseum‚Äã's Photographic History Collection.

Real photo postcards, made on thick photo paper with the postcard info pre-printed on the back, were popular from around 1900 to World War I.

In 1907, postal regulations changed to allow senders to put messages AND addresses on the back‚Äîbefore, only addresses went there. This kept the front free from writing and the image unmarked.

It's #NationalGardenMonth! 
@smithsoniangardens redesigns this area in symmetrical patterns every few seasons, and we‚Äôre digging these new üå∑üå∑üå∑. This space behind our Castle building is called The Parterre (from the French for ‚Äúon the ground‚Äù), which is a style typically associated with the Victorian era.

‚ÄúThat belongs in a museum!‚Äù While the Ruby Slippers step out, you'll still be able to see iconic American entertainment objects at our @amhistorymuseum: props from "Indiana Jones." A hat and whip Harrison Ford used in the film series will go on display where the Ruby Slippers are now. (The shoes will undergo some much-needed conservation‚Äîthe last day to see them for a while is April 23.) We promise to keep the snakes far away.

The Ruby Slippers are off to see the Wizard in the conservation lab.üë† April 23 is the last day to see them for a while at @amhistorymuseum. 
Dorothy (played by Judy Garland) wore them in the 1939 film ‚ÄúThe Wizard of Oz,‚Äù and they‚Äôve been on display almost continuously since their donation to the museum in 1979. Now they‚Äôre showing their age. 
Last fall, nearly 6,500 fans donated to our Kickstarter campaign, #KeepThemRuby. With that help, the Ruby Slippers will be getting some much-needed conservation and will be placed in a new state-of-the-art case to keep them sparkling for generations to come.

Once thought to be extinct, black-footed ferrets are rebounding through Smithsonian science. 
The recovery of the species started with just 18 animals, whose offspring came to the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute in 1988. Since then, 726 black-footed ferrets have been born there, and several hundred of those have been reintroduced to the wild. 
It‚Äôs one of many conservation success stories that will be shared at our #EarthOptimism Summit, held over Earth Day weekend. We‚Äôre convening scientists, thought leaders, philanthropists, conservationists and civic leaders to highlight what‚Äôs working in conservation. Follow along on Facebook and Twitter with #EarthOptimism.
posts.localization: Smithsonian‚Äôs National Zoo and Conservation Biology Institute
